title: What Are the Symptoms of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Myalgic encephalomyelitis/ chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), also called Systemic Exertion Intolerance Disease (SEID), is more than feeling tired all the time. It comes with a lot of other symptoms that can make it hard to handle daily life. Even simple things like walking to the mailbox or writing a letter can make it worse. The fatigue and symptoms can last 6 months , or can go on for years. Sleep and rest don’t make it better, either.
A doctor can help relieve your symptoms, but first, you need to get diagnosed.
If you have ME/CFS, you’ll have these three “core” symptoms:
Along with the three symptoms, you must have one of these for a diagnosis of chronic fatigue syndrome:
bullets: Reduced ability to do usual activities for six months or more because of fatigue
Worsening of symptoms (difficulty thinking, problems sleeping, sore throat , headaches, feeling dizzy, or severe tiredness). after usual physical or mental activity
Trouble falling asleep or staying asleep
Worsening of symptoms while standing or sitting upright; you might feel lightheaded, dizzy, or weak, and you may have blurred vision or see spots.

sections.heading: When to Call a Doctor
content: If you have any of these symptoms and believe you have ME/CFS, talk to your doctor.
You may want to ask about their experience in treating the condition. You can also request a referral or choose to get a second opinion .

sources: CDC: Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome : Symptoms.
Office on Women’s Health: “Chronic fatigue syndrome.”
meta_description: Chronic fatigue syndrome isn’t just about feeling tired all the time. The condition brings a number of other symptoms that can interfere with daily life. WebMD explains.
